CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 10;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient;Costs and expenses - claim dismissed
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE ) . He is a lawyer and Chairman of ORG .

CARDINAL . In DATE a group composed of members of parliament and the ORG sought a ruling from ORG that ORG ( Law no . CARDINAL-XIV ) was unconstitutional . The LAW laid down , inter alia , that all lawyers practising in GPE should be members of ORG , a national association of all lawyers from the local Bars . They argued that compulsory membership of ORG was contrary to the right of freedom of association guaranteed by LAW .

CARDINAL . After consulting , inter alia , ORG , which expressed the view that the LAW was consistent with the LAW , ORG held in a decision of DATE that the provisions making membership of ORG compulsory were unconstitutional .
CARDINAL . The applicant criticised ORG decision in a telephone interview he gave to TIME , a journalist on ORG ( “ Economic Analysis ” ) newspaper .

CARDINAL . NORP In the DATE edition of the newspaper , TIME published an article on the debate which ORG decision of DATE had sparked off among lawyers . He gave the following account of his telephone interview with the applicant :

“ ... After ORG decision was made public , ORG put a series of questions to the Chairman of ORG , PERSON . His comments are tinged with emotion , no doubt because they were made in the heat of the moment :

‘ ORG decision will produce total anarchy in the legal profession’ , said PERSON . ‘ You will see what will happen over the course of DATE . From now on , we no longer have a single system for organising the profession or a unitarian ORG . We have become accustomed to DATE it is easier to live and work in chaos . Taxes are not paid , there is no supervision and , consequently , no ethics , no discipline and no responsibility .

In view of this , the question is whether ORG is constitutional . In DATE ORG adopted its Basic Principles on ORG , which are fully guaranteed by our law . The legal profession is independent the world over . In GPE it is subordinate to the executive , that is to say ORG . This is a serious breach of fundamental democratic principles .

ORG did not take into account the judgments of ORG referred to by ORG in its observations . The judges of ORG probably do not regard ORG as an authority . Am I to assume that they have acquired more experience in DATE than the GPE judges in CARDINAL ? We shall certainly be informing ORG that GPE does not comply with the case - law or requirements of ORG Rights.’

According to Mr ORG , lawyers have always been regarded as being at the forefront of the legal profession : ‘ Despite everything , even after ORG decision , the body of lawyers remains a force.’ ... ”

CARDINAL . In a letter of DATE , the President of ORG informed the applicant that his remarks as reported in the ORG newspaper could constitute a lack of regard for the court within the meaning of LAW ( e ) of LAW and invited him to submit written observations on this point within DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted the requested observations . He said that he had only learned of the publication of his remarks from the letter of DATE and confirmed having had a long telephone conversation with the journalist TIME about the decision of DATE . He stressed , however , that his remarks had been misquoted and largely taken out of context . He added that , had TIME submitted the article to him prior to publication , he would have checked the presentation of his remarks carefully and , accordingly , assumed full responsibility for them .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued a final decision pursuant to Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW in which it imposed an administrative fine on the applicant in the sum of CARDINAL NORP lei ( equivalent to MONEY ) .

It found that the applicant had made the following comments in the aforementioned interview : “ ORG decision will produce total anarchy in the legal profession . ... the question is whether ORG is constitutional . ... The judges of ORG ... do not regard ORG as an authority . ” It found that these comments showed a lack of respect on the applicant ’s part for ORG and its decision .
CARDINAL . As ORG decision was final , the applicant paid the sum of CARDINAL lei into ORG account on DATE .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW read as follows :

“ In order to protect the dignity of the Constitutional Court judges and the participants in the proceedings , and to secure appropriate conditions for the exercise of constitutional jurisdiction , the ORG may take the measures provided for in LAW . ”
“ CARDINAL . In order to ensure the proper administration of constitutional justice , the ORG may impose an administrative fine of CARDINAL times the minimum monthly salary on anyone who :
( a ) makes an unconstitutional statement , regardless of the manner of its expression ;
( b ) interferes with the procedural activity of the Constitutional Court judges , or attempts to influence them by non - procedural methods ;

( c ) refuses without due cause to comply with the orders of the judges of ORG in the prescribed manner or within the time allowed , or fails to comply with a judgment or advisory opinion of the ORG ;
( d ) violates the judicial oath ;

( e ) displays a lack of respect for ORG by refusing to obey orders of the presiding judge , violating disciplinary rules or committing other acts that show an obvious lack of regard for the ORG and its procedure .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL of DATE ) provides :

“ Publishers of periodicals ... shall have a discretion as to the documents and information they choose to publish , but shall have regard to the fact that , since it carries with it duties and responsibilities , the exercise of these freedoms is subject to such formalities , conditions , restrictions or penalties as are prescribed by law and are necessary in a NORP society , in the interests of national security , territorial integrity or public safety , for the prevention of disorder or crime , for the protection of health or morals , for the protection of the reputation or rights of others , for preventing the disclosure of information received in confidence , or for maintaining the authority and impartiality of the judiciary . ”
